item.title: Lab opening
item.description: The lab is opening in October! Join our team to help develop new methods and algorithms to help us understand treatment-resistance in cancer and create new computational tools to improve diagnosis and guide therapy. We are accepting applications for all levels, from graduate student to postdoctoral fellow, as well as software engineers and bioinformaticians.

item.title: Open Positions
item.description: We are hiring for all levels! From graduate student to postdoctoral fellow, we are looking for enthusiastic trainees who want to develop computational methods to understand treatment-resistance in cancer, cancer evolution, cancer heterogeneity, multi-omic analyses, and more! We are also looking for software engineerings and bioinformaticians that are excited about creating new types of data visualizations and interfaces to make our tools widely accessible.

item.title: Research
item.description: Chemotherapy and targeted drugs are effective treatments against cancer, but commonly lead to treatment-resistant cancer cells. Cancer heterogeneity is known to play a significant role in contributing towards this resistance. In order to overcome treatment-resistance in cancer, our goal is to develop new computational methods and algorithms to quantify and visualize cancer heterogeneity to better understand the underlying mechanisms of resistance. To accomplish this goal, we are creating new integrative tools at different scales (such as between cancer subtypes or between individual cells within a single cancer population) and data modalities (such as the transcriptome and the epigenome) to guide therapy.
